questions.question_text: Which of the following code blocks returns a new DataFrame that is the result of a cross join between DataFrame storesDF and DataFrame employeesDF?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is the answer

questions.question_text: Which of the following code blocks returns a new DataFrame that is the result of a position-wise union between DataFrame storesDF and DataFrame acquiredStoresDF?

In what order should the below lines of code be run in order to read a parquet at the file path filePath into a DataFrame?

Lines of code:

1. storesDF
2. .load(filePath, source = "parquet")
3. .read \
4. spark \
5. .read() \
6. .parquet(filePath)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
E is correct. read is a property of spark. so spark.read(). is wrong. B is wrong.

Selected Answer: E
E is right

Selected Answer: E
E is correct

questions.question_text:
The code block shown below should read a CSV at the file path filePath into a DataFrame with the specified schema schema. Choose the response that correctly fills in the numbered blanks within the code block to complete this task.

Code block:

__1__.__2__.__3__(__4__).format("csv").__5__(__6__)

choices.A: Slots are the most coarse level of execution in the Spark execution hierarchy.
choices.B: Slots are resource threads that can be used for parallelization within a Spark application.
choices.D: Slots are the most granular level of execution in the Spark execution hierarchy.
choices.E: Slots are unique segments of data from a DataFrame that are split up by row.
choices.C: Slots are resources that are used to run multiple Spark applications at once on a single cluster.

discussion.content: B. Slots are resource threads that can be used for parallelization within a Spark application.
